abstract: pmc Cell Stress Chaperones Cell Stress Chaperones 127 celstres Cell Stress & Chaperones 1355-8145 1466-1268 Elsevier PMC12478251 PMC12478251.1 12478251 12478251 40935014 10.1016/j.cstres.2025.100113 S1355-8145(25)00058-6 100113 1 Research Article TBX5-AS1 induces ER stress and suppresses lung cancer growth and tumor stemness via the miR-494-3p/ATF6 axis Wang Guoqin 1 # Fu Chaojiang 2 # Tu Changling 3 Yang Zhuangqing 4 Shi Wei 5 Zhang Lijuan 6 Tan Shufen shufen591@hotmail.com 7 ⁎ Huang Youguang huangyouguang2008@126.com 8 ⁎ 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 ⁎ shufen591@hotmail.com huangyouguang2008@126.com # Guoqin Wang and Chaojiang Fu contributed equally to this work. 12 2025 09 9 2025 30 6 497782 100113 19 5 2025 3 9 2025 4 9 2025 09 09 2025 30 09 2025 30 09 2025 © 2025 The Authors. Published by Elsevier Inc. on behalf of Cell Stress Society International. 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/). Tumor stemness maintenance and endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress response have been strongly correlated with the progression of lung cancer (LC). Nevertheless, the role of long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) in these processes remains incompletely understood. We screened LC-associated lncRNAs from the GEO database and validated the expression of TBX5-AS1 in clinical samples. Functional experiments were conducted to assess the biological effects of TBX5-AS1, and western blot was used to detect ER stress marker proteins. The interaction mechanism of the TBX5-AS1/miR-494–3p/ATF6 axis was elucidated through dual-luciferase reporter assays, RNA immunoprecipitation (RIP), and pull-down experiments. Rescue experiments and a nude mouse xenograft model were employed to validate the functional outcomes. TBX5-AS1 was significantly downregulated in LC tissues and cell lines, and its low expression was associated with advanced tumor stages and poor patient prognosis. Overexpression of TBX5-AS1 markedly suppressed LC cell proliferation, migration, invasion, and self-renewal while promoting the activation of the ER stress pathway. Mechanistically, TBX5-AS1 competitively binds to miR-494–3p, thereby relieving its transcriptional repression of Activating transcription factor 6 (ATF6). Rescue experiments demonstrated that miR-494–3p overexpression reversed the regulatory effects of TBX5-AS1 on tumor malignant phenotype and ER stress. In vivo experiments further confirmed that TBX5-AS1 overexpression significantly inhibited tumor growth, accompanied by upregulation of ATF6 and ER stress-related proteins. TBX5-AS1 functioned as a tumor-suppressive lncRNA by activating ER stress signaling through the miR-494–3p/ATF6 axis, thereby inhibiting LC growth and tumor stemness. Highlights • TBX5-AS1 was obviously downregulated in LC. • TBX5-AS1 inhibited LC progression by miR-494-3p/ATF6. • TBX5-AS1 activated ER stress signaling and inhibited tumor stemness. Keywords TBX5-AS1 ER stress Tumor stemness MiR-494–3p ATF6 pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement yes pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes Introduction Globally, lung cancer (LC) persists as the predominant etiology of malignancy-associated mortality, demonstrating a 5-year overall survival (OS) rate below 20%. Its high invasiveness and drug resistance are closely linked to cancer stemness. 1 2 3 4 Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) serve as pivotal regulators of gene expression, modulating diverse biological pathways. The competing endogenous RNA (ceRNA) theory posits that lncRNAs can sequester miRNAs to indirectly regulate mRNA targets, a mechanism extensively documented in oncogenesis. 5 6 7 8 9 10 11 12 13 Activating transcription factor 6 (ATF6) is a transmembrane glycoprotein and transcription activator that plays a role in initiating the UPR signaling pathway during ER stress. 14 15 16 3 In this study, we identified TBX5-AS1 as significantly downregulated in LC tissues. Further experiments revealed that TBX5-AS1 overexpression competitively bound to miR-494–3p, relieving its repression of ATF6 and activating ER stress pathways, thereby significantly impairing tumor cell self-renewal. Our findings highlighted the biological role of TBX5-AS1 in LC and its molecular mechanism of regulating ER stress and tumor stemness through the miR-494–3p/ATF6 axis. Results TBX5-AS1 was downregulated in LC and correlated with tumor progression and poor prognosis Through bioinformatics analysis of the GSE31210 12 Figure 1 Figure 1 Figure 1 Figure 1 Figure 1 Figure 1 Fig. 1 TBX5-AS1 expression was downregulated in LC. GSE31210 n Fig. 1 Overexpression of TBX5-AS1 inhibited LC cell proliferation, migration, invasion, and tumor stemness To investigate the functional consequences of TBX5-AS1 dysregulation, we established TBX5-AS1 overexpression cell lines, with transfection efficiency confirmed by RT-qPCR ( Figure 2 Figure 2 Figure 2 Figure 2 Figure 2 Figure 2 Figure 2 Figure 2 Fig. 2 Overexpression of TBX5-AS1 inhibited the proliferation, migration, invasion, and stemness of LC cells. Fig. 2 Overexpression of TBX5-AS1 enhanced ER stress to inhibit tumor progression Given the potential link between TBX5-AS1 and ER stress suggested by our above findings, we further investigated the expression of key ER stress-related proteins in TBX5-AS1-overexpressing LC cells to validate this functional association. To induce endoplasmic ER stress in LC cells, we treated them with thapsigargin, a well-established pharmacological inducer of ER stress. Western blot analysis showed that thapsigargin significantly upregulated the expression of ER stress-related proteins (ATF4, CHOP, and GRP78), confirming its potent ER stress-inducing activity. Notably, overexpression of TBX5-AS1 similarly led to a marked increase in the levels of these stress markers, with an effect comparable to that of thapsigargin treatment. This indicates that TBX5-AS1 effectively activates the ER stress pathway in LC cells. Moreover, the upregulation of these proteins could be synergistically enhanced by Thapsigargin and TBX5-AS1 ( Figure 3 Figure 3 Fig. 3 Overexpression of TBX5-AS1 suppressed the proliferation, metastasis, and stemness of LC cells by enhancing ER stress. Fig. 3 TBX5-AS1 regulated ATF6 expression by competitively binding to miR-494-3p Subcellular localization analysis revealed that TBX5-AS1 is predominantly distributed in the cytoplasm ( Figure 4 17 Figure 4 Fig. 4 TBX5-AS1 mediated ATF6 expression through interacting with miR-494–3p. Fig. 4 To validate this regulatory axis, wild-type (wt) and mutant (mut) dual-luciferase reporter plasmids for TBX5-AS1 and ATF6 were constructed ( Figure 4 Figure 4 Figure 4 Supplementary Figure S1 Supplementary Figure S1 Figure 4 Figure 4 Figure 4 Figure 4 TBX5-AS1 upregulation promoted ATF6 expression by sponging miR-494-3p, then affected the growth, metastasis, stemness, and ER stress in LC cells To elucidate the functional role of the TBX5-AS1/miR-494–3p/ATF6 axis in the progression of LC, we conducted co-transfection of miR-494–3p mimics in TBX5-AS1-overexpressing LC cells. Western blot analysis revealed that TBX5-AS1 overexpression significantly upregulated ATF6 protein expression, which was substantially attenuated by miR-494–3p mimic supplementation ( Figure 5 Figure 5 Figure 5 Figure 5 Figure 5 Figure 5 Figure 5 Fig. 5 TBX5-AS1 upregulation promoted ATF6 expression by sponging miR-494–3p, then affected the growth, metastasis, stemness, and ER stress in LC cells. Fig. 5 Overexpressing TBX5-AS1 hindered tumor growth and induced ER stress in LC cells in vivo To validate the in vivo function of TBX5-AS1, a subcutaneous xenograft tumor model in nude mice was established. The results showed that both tumor volume and weight were measurably reduced in the LV-oe-TBX5-AS1 group compared to controls ( Figure 6 Figure 6 Figure 6 Fig. 6 Investigating the role of TBX5-AS1 in cell growth and ER stress of LC cells in vivo. Fig. 6 Discussion LncRNAs play critical regulatory roles in tumorigenesis and can function as either oncogenes or tumor suppressors in various cancers, including LC. 18 19 13 11 Functional investigations revealed that overexpression of TBX5-AS1 noticeably attenuated malignant phenotypes, including cellular proliferation and migratory capacity in LC, aligning with existing reports documenting its oncosuppressive properties in non-small cell lung cancer. 11 20 The ceRNA mechanism has been widely validated as an important way for lncRNAs to regulate tumor progression. For example, lncRNA-PNUTS modulates migratory and invasive capacities in A549 and NMuMG cell lines via specific miR-205 binding domain interactions. 21 22 23 24 25 25 26 Notably, among the potential downstream targets of miR-494–3p, ATF6 was predicted by bioinformatics and experimentally validated as a direct target gene. ATF6 is a key sensor of the unfolded protein response pathway and functions as a transcription factor during ER stress, regulating a series of genes involved in maintaining protein homeostasis. In recent years, accumulating evidence has demonstrated that ATF6 not only participates in tumor growth and invasion but also plays a critical role in modulating tumor cell subpopulations with stem-like properties and in reshaping the tumor microenvironment. 3 27 28 29 In summary, this study not only further validates the tumor-suppressive role of TBX5-AS1 in LC but also elucidates a previously uncharacterized molecular mechanism by which TBX5-AS1 regulates ER stress and tumor stemness via the TBX5-AS1/miR-494–3p/ATF6 axis. This discovery functionally links the lncRNA-ceRNA regulatory network with the unfolded protein response signaling pathway, expanding the regulatory scope of non-coding RNAs in tumor stress responses, and provides potential new therapeutic targets and theoretical foundations for the precision treatment of LC. Conclusion In conclusion, this study revealed a novel mechanism by which TBX5-AS1 enhanced the ER stress through the ceRNA-mediated miR-494–3p/ATF6 axis, thereby inhibiting LC growth and stemness. This discovery not only enriches the theoretical framework of non-coding RNA regulation in tumor stemness but also provides a theoretical basis for developing new therapeutic strategies targeting the ER stress pathway. Materials and methods Clinical specimens This study was approved by the ethics committee of The Third Affiliated Hospital of Kunming Medical University (Yunnan Cancer Hospital). LC patients who did not receive chemotherapy or radiotherapy were selected to be included in the scope of the trial. Adjacent non-tumor tissues and tumor tissues were collected from patients at the same time. All patients or their guardians signed informed consent. Experiments involving human tissue specimens complied with the declaration of Helsinki. Cell culture and transfection HBE cells and four pulmonary carcinoma cell lines (A549, PC9, H23, and H1299) were procured from ATCC (USA). Cell cultures were maintained in RPMI-1640 medium (Gibco, USA) containing 10% FBS (Gibco) and 1% penicillin/streptomycin (Sigma-Aldrich, USA) under standard culture conditions (5% CO 2 TBX5-AS1 was overexpressed using two complementary systems. For transient overexpression in vitro, a pcDNA3.1-based plasmid containing a 3655 bp insert corresponding to the reference transcript of TBX5-AS1 (RefSeq: NR_038440.1 OV288968 HL288968 For transient transfection experiments, 2×10 5 Western blot analysis Protein lysates were prepared with RIPA buffer (Beyotime, China) and electrophoresed on 10% SDS-PAGE gels prior to electrotransfer onto PVDF membranes (Millipore, USA). Following blocking with 5% non-fat milk, immunoblotting was performed with specific primary antibodies: ATF6 (ab203119, 1:500), CHOP (ab11419, 1:1000), GRP78 (ab230508, 1:100), ATF4 (ab31390, 1:1000), and GAPDH (ab9485, 1:2000; all from Abcam, UK). HRP-conjugated secondary antibodies (1:5000, Proteintech, China) were employed for chemiluminescent detection using ECL substrate (Millipore), with imaging conducted on a ChemiDoc MP system (Bio-Rad, USA). RT-qPCR analysis Total RNA was isolated from pulmonary tissues and cell lines using TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen), followed by DNase I digestion (Takara, Japan) to eliminate genomic DNA contamination. cDNA synthesis was performed with PrimeScript RT Master Mix (Takara), and quantitative PCR was carried out using SYBR Premix Ex Taq II (Takara). Gene expression quantification utilized the comparative Ct (2-ΔΔCt) method with primer sequences detailed in Supplementary Table S1 Subcellular localization assessment Subcellular localization was determined using the PARISTM Kit (Thermo Fisher, USA) for nuclear/cytoplasmic fractionation. RNA from each fraction was purified with TRIzol (Invitrogen) and analyzed via RT-qPCR quantification. CCK-8 assay 3×10 3 Colony formation assay To evaluate the proliferative potential of LC cells following genetic modulation, a clonogenic survival assay was performed. Briefly, cells were seeded into 6-well tissue culture plates at a density of 1000 cells per well 24 h after transfection and allowed to attach overnight under standard culture conditions. After 24 h, the culture medium was replaced with fresh growth medium, and cells were maintained for an additional 14 days with periodic medium replenishment every 3-4 days to ensure nutrient availability. Upon completion of the incubation period, colonies were gently washed with PBS, fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde for 15 min at room temperature, and stained with 0.5% crystal violet solution for 20 min. Excess dye was removed by thorough washing with distilled water. Colonies containing more than 50 cells were photographed using a phase-contrast microscope (Olympus IX73) and manually counted. Wound healing assay Cells were seeded in 6-well plates (5×10 5 Transwell invasion analysis Matrigel-precoated Transwell chambers (Corning) were hydrated with 50 μL basal matrix for 1 h prior to use. Cellular suspensions (5×10 5 Tumorsphere formation assay Dissociated single cells (1×10 3 Dual-luciferase reporter assay The 3' untranslated region sequences of TBX5-AS1/ATF6 (wt and mut variants) were cloned into pmirGLO dual-reporter vectors (Promega, USA). Transient co-transfection was performed in pulmonary carcinoma cells using 100 ng reporter plasmids combined with 50 nM miR-494–3p mimics (RiboBio) or control oligonucleotides. Relative luciferase activity was quantified 48 h post-transfection using a dual-detection kit (Beyotime), with Renilla luciferase serving as the internal normalization control. RIP RIP experiments were conducted using magnetic bead-conjugated anti-Ago2 (ab186733, Abcam) or isotype-matched IgG (ab172730, Abcam). Cellular lysates were subjected to immunoprecipitation with antibody-coated beads (Thermo Fisher), followed by RNA isolation and subsequent quantification via RT-qPCR. In vivo experiment Female BALB/c nude mice (6-week-old, Vital River, China) were housed under specific pathogen-free conditions and randomized into experimental cohorts ( n 6 Statistical analysis Quantitative data are expressed as mean ± standard deviation. Intergroup differences were analyzed by unpaired Student's t http://ualcan.path.uab.edu t P Ethics statement This study was approved by the Ethics Committee of The Third Affiliated Hospital of Kunming Medical University (Yunnan Cancer Hospital). All participants were provided with written informed consent at the time of recruitment, and all experiments involving human tissue specimens comply with the Declaration of Helsinki Funding and support This study was supported by Yunnan Fundamental Research Projects (grant No. 202401AY070001–329). metadata.Title of this paper: Targeting the ATF6-mediated ER stress response and autophagy blocks integrin-driven prostate cancer progression
